Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"​

How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning "

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"​
​Communication skills
"
How this is developed:
"Tutorials, self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To develop in students an understanding of the use of evolutionary theory to understand animal behaviour;

To develop in students the ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding, to solve complex problems in the study of behaviour;

To develop in students an understanding how predictive modelling, experimental, and observational approaches integrate to explain animal behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module addresses contemporary topics in animal behaviour within an evolutionary framework. It combines current experimental and field research and links behaviour to other areas including ecology, neurobiology, comparative cognition and human evolution. The module is delivered through traditional lectures and a combination of guided and self-directed reading. The module is assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Evolution of reproductive systems;

Co-operation, altruism, societies and conflict;

Applied animal behaviour, including the importance of animal welfare, food security and both in situ and ex situ conservation;

Individual variation in behaviour; alternate strategies; parasite manipulation; evolution of superstition;

Cognitive basis of behaviour and humans as animals: comparative approaches to cognitive; evolution of the vertebrate brains; self-awareness, intentionality and theory of mind;

Module material will be delivered primarily through lectures. Independent learning is supported by materials on Canvas such as lecture hand-outs and other web-based resources.

Small group tutorials will be used to guide students’ in-course assignment. Students will be guided to key articles in the literature, e.g. textbooks, original papers and review articles and will be expected to use these materials to supplement their independent learning.

Formative assessment exercises will test students’ knowledge and ability to solve problems; students will be offered individual feedback on assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled 1 hr lectures that explain key concepts
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to tutorials in which in-course assignments are discussed and feedback is provided
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans forteaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
There are 2 assessments.

Assessment 1 is written coursework (40%). A primer on a current field of animal behaviour research.

Assessment 2. Extended writing (60%) in which students are asked to critically review an aspect of the study of animal behaviour with specific reference to the themes covered in the module.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

To develop in students an understanding how predictive modelling, experimental, and observational approaches integrate to explain animal behaviour.

This module addresses contemporary topics in animal behaviour within an evolutionary framework. It combines current experimental and field research and links behaviour to other areas including ecology, neurobiology, comparative cognition and human evolution. The module is delivered through traditional lectures and a combination of guided and self-directed reading. The module is assessed by continuous assessment.

Co-operation, altruism, societies and conflict;

Applied animal behaviour, including the importance of animal welfare, food security and both in situ and ex situ conservation;

Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled 1 hr lectures that explain key concepts
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to tutorials in which in-course assignments are discussed and feedback is provided
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans forteaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

There are 2 assessments.

Assessment 2. Extended writing (60%) in which students are asked to critically review an aspect of the study of animal behaviour with specific reference to the themes covered in the module.

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans forteaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
There are 2 assessments.

Assessment 1 is written coursework (40%). A primer on a current field of animal behaviour research.

Assessment 2. Extended writing (60%) in which students are asked to critically review an aspect of the study of animal behaviour with specific reference to the themes covered in the module.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Educational Aims
To develop in students an understanding of the use of evolutionary theory to understand animal behaviour;

To develop in students the ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding, to solve complex problems in the study of behaviour;

To develop in students an understanding how predictive modelling, experimental, and observational approaches integrate to explain animal behaviour.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module addresses contemporary topics in animal behaviour within an evolutionary framework. It combines current experimental and field research and links behaviour to other areas including ecology, neurobiology, comparative cognition and human evolution. The module is delivered through traditional lectures and a combination of guided and self-directed reading. The module is assessed by continuous assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Evolution of reproductive systems;

Co-operation, altruism, societies and conflict;

Applied animal behaviour, including the importance of animal welfare, food security and both in situ and ex situ conservation;

Individual variation in behaviour; alternate strategies; parasite manipulation; evolution of superstition;

Cognitive basis of behaviour and humans as animals: comparative approaches to cognitive; evolution of the vertebrate brains; self-awareness, intentionality and theory of mind;

Module material will be delivered primarily through lectures. Independent learning is supported by materials on Canvas such as lecture hand-outs and other web-based resources.

Small group tutorials will be used to guide students’ in-course assignment. Students will be guided to key articles in the literature, e.g. textbooks, original papers and review articles and will be expected to use these materials to supplement their independent learning.

Formative assessment exercises will test students’ knowledge and ability to solve problems; students will be offered individual feedback on assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled 1 hr lectures that explain key concepts
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to tutorials in which in-course assignments are discussed and feedback is provided
Attendance Recorded: Yes
